data.sampled:
In mathematical logic, the expression (false and not not (false or not (true or false))) is an example of a liar paradox, a type of self-contradiction that occurs when a mathematical statement leads to a contradiction.

Unfortunately, it is not possible to determine whether this expression is true or false using standard logical operations. The problem arises because the first part of the expression, (false and not not (false or not (true or false))) contains negations and conjunctions that may not always be evaluable using standard boolean logic.

In general, talking about negatives and conjunctions in boolean logic can be a complex and computationally expensive process, and it is not always possible to determine whether a given statement is true or false using this approach alone. Therefore, it is often necessary to use additional techniques, such as model-checking or truth tables, to validate logic expressions.
